div1.head: Jim to Mr. Paul A. Rockwell July 25th [1916] Tues.
div1.p:
Glad to get your good letter this noon along with prints. Sorry the one of Kiffin and you didn’t come out. Next time you’re up we’ll do better. Would you mind ordering ten prints for me of my picture and four three of yours & one of machine up side down. [?] Have em [sic] send bill to me and let me know
how much I owe you now.
There’s no doubt about Skipper being sent to us. Expect him any day now that he’s at R. G. R.
Interesting dope about the young V. S. Aers. in Aviation. The French ought to stop letting them in. Lovell at Buc is a fine chap, tho [sic].

I’m on guard to day and so am not flying. Just letting flies in tent bother me. De Laage and Kiffin have just gone out to act as guard for Prince
who loaded down with sky rockets is off after a Boche observation sausage.

Page, editor of World’s Work wanted article on American Aviators so he wrote Eyre and suggested getting me to do it. Eyre just wants dope and experience stuff and says he’ll write it. I felt sort of hurt that Page didn’t write direct. Told Eyre I wouldn’t have it run under my name unless I wrote it but he tells me its got to
appear in personal, and unless I wanted to conform to turn over job to Prince Johnson or Cowden. Well I need the 75 bones [sic] and so I’ll conform.
My little deal with the Sun has proved lucrative but don’t tell old Grundy. He might cut down on rates. Hope to get enough to see me through on permission.

I’ll write Marcelle about not sending her address. She’s at Hotel Ermitage, Evian les Baines, Hte. Savoie.
The girl of shattered life has written to me but once since I left after my 48 hr. stay. I am losing interest in the girls I know, anyway, for some unknown reason.

You are sure right Paul about the boys in trenches not getting what they deserve. They are fighting the whole war and bearing all the misery. Every damn one of them ought to be made happy for life after the fights over.
Sorry to hear the Legion caught it so badly. I had been under the impression that our losses were slight.

Hall got another Boche. Great work eh [sic]! Rumsey and Hill made sergeants and Prince adjudant [sic]. Hill is good, and a nervy pilot. I hope he smears several Boches — but God in Boston its a hard job.

Balsley being moved to Paris. Arrives Thurs. or Fri. morning.
Out of 11 machines in escadrille only four are in commission at present moment from various causes. We’ll all be ready tho [sic] tomorrow. Prince damn near ran into me on landing and made a swerve with result he tipped over. Lufbery had a terrible smash. We thought him dead but he hadn’t a scratch. Sick now from gasoline he swallowed.

Lieut. Chaput terribly wounded yesterday, but
managed to get back.
Wrote a line or so on what American aviators thought of going back. Made it hot. See Americans are going to be advised to leave Turkey instead of government sticking up for them. Can you beat it?
Keep me posted, old top and keep your spirits up. Don’t let the capard get you.
